text: hey everyone Anthony Fantino here
internets busiest music nerd and it is
time for a review of this new pop smoke
record shoot for the stars aim for the
moon this is the posthumous commercial
debut album of New York rapper pop smoke
who was tragically slain this past
February the same month he put out meet
the whoa vol 2 the sequel to his
breakout mixtape in 2019 now obviously I
didn't know pop smoke so I can't speak
to the personal devastation and loss
that has come with his death but I can
say as an observer of music that the
artistic potential lost here is pretty
great especially considering the
creative lane that he inhabited rising
to the top of New York's burgeoning
drill scene thanks to his hit single
welcome to the party if you're unaware
New York drill is one of the most
interesting musical anomalies out there
right now if you've been paying
attention long enough when you think of
drill your mind most likely goes to
Chicago and thinks of artists like lil
Bibby and G er Bo and Chief Keef and
Fredo Santana but the genre has been
popping off in a revitalized form in the
UK now for a while with artists from
South London incorporating different
flows instrumental ideas lingo and of
course accents into this very aggressive
and violent brand of rap music so
interestingly enough that strain of
drill has been coming back around and
influencing artists from the Big Apple
to the point where on their tracks some
of them sound hella British for example
check out the track no suburban from
chef G total banger energy out of this
world it's a great track but the sound
of his voice the sound of the
instrumental it's hard to believe this
song was made stateside so it's crazy
such a thing could then garner
mainstream attention with a guy like pop
smoke being the conduit but he arguably
had one of the more unique voices and
styles to come out of New York in a
while his original meet the woo tape is
packed with dark rhythmically intricate
instrumentals moody tones and a voice
that literally sounds like the vocal
representation of smoke his delivery on
that project his flows on that project
brought sounding cold-blooded to a new
level
the original meet the whoo may be short
but it is a very consistent tape in
terms of sound and quality pretty
interest
to catch a very clear 50 cent influence
on the track PTSD - plus it's admirable
that he absolutely stuck to his
stylistic guns on meet the woo part - as
he crossed over with artists that make
more straightforward and I guess trendy
styles of trap nav boogie quavo of me
goes but shoot for the moon aim for the
stars is not just another helping of New
York drill it is a commercial debut and
it sounds like it meaning that it's a
little all over the place there is a
massive tracklist here it is packed with
features some of which seemed to take
priority over pop smoke on these tracks
and there's a somewhat uneven mix of
bangers and slow jams on this record -
which wasn't as much the case for his
previous stuff especially meet the whoo
Part 1 which was just heat heat heat
heat heat track after track now being
this is a posthumous record that is
executive produced by 50 cent it is hard
to know whether or not this is the
record that pop smoke would have
released had he been alive to put it out
like with Mac Miller circles earlier
this year there seems to have been at
least some collective effort in bringing
this thing to completion and thankfully
the finished product here sounds like a
complete album with structured songs not
just a bunch of random odds and ends
that are filled out with mediocre
instrumentals and features that go on
too long or just repeated lines that are
copied and pasted so at the very least
regardless of what you think about the
music on this project it does not come
off immediately like a cheap cash grab
sure the features might be a little
excessive like quavo on this thing three
times pop smoke also having the shortest
and final verse on the song the whoo
which leaves them feeling like an
afterthought on his own track now this
isn't to say that there are highlights
on this project there are but the heat
that you may find all over meet the blue
parts 1 & 2 is here but in a somewhat
limited capacity there is aim for the
moon featuring an intricate drill be
nimble bass lots of moody swirling tones
pop smokes gruff relentless flow pretty
typical formula for him but it works
quavo also features on the track and I
think his auto-tuned and Atmospheric
vocal lines add a lot to the song space
the chord change on the hook is quite
nice - the song 44 bulldog is
more raw and less melodic in tone with
its regal and grim chord progression
also the somewhat low Phi and very loud
ad-libs that almost overtake pop smokes
voice in the mix it adds a very odd
character to the song for the ad-libs to
be this loud but again pop smoke doesn't
really get lost in focus because his
voice is so unique the way it's
overdubbed how devilish and slick and
shadowy 'sounds gangsta's is another
smoked track that sounds like yet
another 50 cent or g-unit callback not
only do his vocal line sound like
something 50 would have sung back in the
day but the instrumental too is like
something that would have hit in the
2000s you can tell that personally pop
smoke is a student of this bling era
gangsta rap sound because he does it so
much justice lyrically he's not fooling
around either saying 44 got a kick back
click-clack get back shots at your rib
pack or you can get chin checked the
song creature with sway Lee goes over
better than I expected considering sway
Lee is on it I don't think he's had an
amazing feature in a while and I think
he brings a pretty catchy vocal line to
this track without getting too much in
pop smokes way over yet another typical
UK drill beat and a very familiar flow
and delivery from him
make it rain though is easily one of the
most hard-hitting and aggressive
murderous songs on the project pop smoke
upping the ante with a trunk knocking B
and a slightly faster flow rowdy rebel
on here of gs9 fame features over the
phone
VA penitentiary call which is becoming
more and more of a thing as of late but
I have to say out of all of these call
features that I have been hearing again
and again and again this is easily one
of the tightest of them it does not
derail the song at all the track got it
on me is a highlight but it also doubles
as a 50 cent tribute of sorts with pop
smoke borrowing vocal lines and lyrics
from 50 Cent's many men which I've never
thought that much of 50 cent as a singer
but pop smoke I think does this classic
hook a lot of justice I think he
revitalizes it I think he brings a lot
of passion to this chorus the song also
features a killer beat more relentless
flows killer lyrics what's not to love
there is even a flow switch up on the
second verse of the song that sounds
like something straight out of the DMX
playbook
so when she
for the moon falters and it does falter
it's usually over some bloated or weak
features like for the night with little
baby and dub a B or the Wu which I was
referring to earlier with 50-cent
Andrade rich where somehow rowdy comes
out ahead on this track with these
elastic lead vocals 50 is seriously
punching under his weight here and then
again pop smoke kind of bringing up the
end with a very short appearance just
doesn't really have that much presence
on the track not as much as I would have
wanted
then finally snitching with quavo and
future is not only not about snitching
but this quavo feature is not one of the
stronger ones here and then the future
appearance on the back end has future
like very awkwardly impersonating pop
smoke going into his lower register and
a very uncharacteristic way I don't know
if this is his attempt at attributing
him or something but it is not very
flattering then there is the track yeah
as well as enjoy yourself which are a
few mellow mmmm the tracklist that don't
really hit all that hard or leave much
of an impression but the only song in
the tracklist that really struck me as
being hard to stomach was mood swings
with little TJ just all of the Nutting
going on in the lyrics combined with
these tactless attempts at being sexy
just came off as very awkward for me
however I don't blame pop smoke for
attempting these slow jam tracks these
more mellow tracks these romantic tracks
or 50 set for including them because
occasionally they do go over well like
with the track something special which
does feature some so-so vocal lines but
it does feel like a genuine smooth
classy love song with pop smoke trying
to take this girl in a shopping spree
there's also a flow and a delivery that
is somewhat reminiscent of Tupac on this
track to the song what you know about
love is equally endearing as well
despite not really expecting to go into
this thing hearing so many love songs so
while yes the tracklist on this thing is
kind of spotty
I still think pop smokes talents and
what made him special as an artist still
translates I mean again some of my least
favorite tracks on here are my least
favorite because they don't feature
enough pop smoke there is also a pretty
point
moment placed very intentionally at the
end of tunnel vision where pop smoke is
being interviewed and being asked what
he would like for his impact on the rap
game to be and he puts his desires
pretty simply saying that he would like
to change the game that he would like to
come in and show people a new sound a
new vibe a new direction and in the
short time that he was making waves pop
smoke unquestionably did that it's just
a shame that he's not still around to do
it today so overall like this project
thought it was pretty decent thought it
had a lot of highlights on it but still
some weak moments that I can't ignore
despite this being a posthumous release
but if you're a pop smoke fan I see no
reason why this should be a total
disappointment or anything like that I'm
feeling a strong six to a light seven on
this transition have you given this
album a listen did you love it did you
hate it what would you rate it you're
the best you're the best what should I
review next hit the like if you like
please subscribe and please don't cry
hit the bell as well over here next to
my head is another video that you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel
Anthony Fantana pop smoke forever
